questions.question: What CPU design philosophy uses complex instructions that can execute several operations?
questions.explanation: CISC processors use complex instructions that can perform multiple operations per instruction, reducing program size but increasing complexity.

questions.question: What is the technique called where CPU executes instructions out of their original program order?
questions.explanation: Out-of-order execution allows the CPU to execute instructions as resources become available, improving performance by avoiding idle time.

questions.question: What predicts whether a conditional branch will be taken to improve pipeline efficiency?
questions.explanation: Branch predictors use algorithms to guess the outcome of conditional branches, reducing pipeline stalls and improving performance.

questions.question: What allows a single CPU core to execute multiple threads simultaneously?
questions.explanation: SMT enables a single physical core to appear as multiple logical processors, improving resource utilization and throughput.

questions.question: What is the name of the unit that renames registers to eliminate false dependencies?
questions.explanation: Register renaming eliminates write-after-write and write-after-read hazards by mapping architectural registers to physical registers.

questions.question: What executes instructions without waiting for preceding instructions to complete?
questions.explanation: Superscalar processors can execute multiple instructions in parallel using multiple execution units within a single core.

questions.question: What buffer stores decoded micro-operations in modern x86 processors?
questions.explanation: The micro-op cache stores decoded instructions to avoid repeated decoding, improving efficiency in modern processors.

questions.question: What is the technique of executing the same instruction on multiple data points simultaneously?
questions.explanation: SIMD allows one instruction to operate on multiple data elements in parallel, commonly used in multimedia and scientific computing.

questions.question: What determines the number of instructions fetched per cycle in superscalar processors?
questions.explanation: Issue width determines how many instructions can be dispatched to execution units simultaneously in a superscalar processor.

questions.question: What is the reorder buffer used for in out-of-order processors?
questions.explanation: The reorder buffer ensures instructions complete in program order despite out-of-order execution, maintaining correct program semantics.
